title-group.article-title: Robust control of automotive engine using active engine mount

article-meta.aff: 1Mechanical Engineering Department, Amirkabir University of Technology, Tehran, Iran
2Noise and Vibration Workgroup, Irankhodro Powertrain Company (IPCo), Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Abdolreza Ohadi, Mechanical Engineering Department, Amirkabir University of Technology, Hafez Avenue 424, Tehran, Iran Email: a_r_ohadi@aut.ac.ir

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this study, the effectiveness of an active engine mount in vibration suppression of a four-cylinder engine is evaluated. Two robust control algorithms, namely H2 and H∞ schemes, are employed to provide control input using accelerations of the engine body in the position of the mounts. In this regard, an accurate engine model is presented and the exciting active engine mount model is employed to design robust controllers. Derivation of equations of motion for an engine on the mounts is performed using Lagrange's and Newton–Euler equations. This derivation of equations has not been presented in any other study. In addition, unstructured uncertainties due to the unmodeled dynamics of the plant, actuator and sensors are considered. Using appropriate weighting functions, two robust control algorithms are designed. Robust stability and robust performance of the proposed controllers are evaluated using µ-analysis. The effectiveness of the proposed controllers, in the presence of sensor noise, in vibration suppression of the engine is evaluated. Results show that active mount with the designed robust controllers can improve the vibration behavior of the engine in the presence of sensor noise.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Passengers on board of a vehicle receive undesired vibration from excitation sources such as the road and engine. Engine mounts are required to isolate the chassis from high-frequency engine vibrations resulting from the rotation of out-of-balance masses and combustion forces. Moreover, they have an important role in reducing transmitted vibrations to the engine from low-frequency road inputs.

Passive mounts (rubber and hydraulic mounts) have been employed in the automotive industry for many years. These mounts are not able to isolate the engine for a wide range of excitation frequencies. In order to further improve the dynamic performance of passive mounts, semi-active and active engine mounts have been introduced. By considering the advantages of semi-active and active engine mounts, some automotive manufacturers are researching to develop these mounts and improve their products. Japanese automotive companies such as Toyota, Nissan and Honda introduced active control mounts to the automotive market (Aoki et al., 1999; Ozaki et al., 1999; Hideki et al., 2004).

Semi-active engine mounts have been developed with electrorheological fluid (Choi et al., 1999), magnethorheological fluid (Arzanpour and Golnaraghi, 2008), engine intake manifold vacuum (Kim and Singh, 1995) and so on. Also, active engine mounts with piezoelectric actuators (Shibayama et al., 1995) and electromagnetic actuators (Nakaji et al., 1999) have been investigated. Various control algorithms have been employed for vibration isolation of automotive engines.

Nakaji et al. (1999) developed and tested an active control engine mount to reduce idling vibration and booming noise in automobile engines. They employed an adaptive control strategy based on the synchronized filtered-X least-mean-square (FXLMS) algorithm for the active mount. Hillis et al. (2005) developed an active engine mount that combines a passive hydraulic mount with an internal electromagnetic actuator. The FXLMS adaptive filter was used as a benchmark for comparison with a new implementation of the error-driven minimal controller synthesis (Er-MCSI) adaptive controller. Both algorithms were applied to the active engine mount and a comparison has been made. Lee and Lee (2009) developed and tested a low-cost prototype active control engine mount without any feedback sensor. A model-based feedforward algorithm, which consists of a vibration estimation algorithm, a current shaping controller and an improved active control mount model, is adopted in order to compensate for the performance degradation due to absence of the feedback sensors.

Uncertainties in the model used for control design is an undeniable fact. Therefore, employing the robust controller schemes is necessary for real-world implementation of the controllers. However, investigations on the development of an active control engine mount with robust controllers are limited in number.

Seba et al. (2005) employed H∞ feedback control and FXLMS feedforward control for engine vibration isolation and compared the performance results obtained with the mentioned controllers. They developed an experimental setup including a chassis subframe, electromechanical shaker, accelerometers and control actuator. The frequency responses from the different inputs to the different outputs of the system were obtained using subspace identification for each path considered separately. Then, the mentioned control algorithms were designed and compared. In the robust controller design, unstructured uncertainties due to the unmodeled dynamics of the plant, actuator and sensors were considered. They simulated engine disturbance using the electromechanical shaker and designed the controllers based on experimental identification. However, no mathematical model for the engine on the mounts and no formulation for the forces and moments applied to the engine were presented by Seba et al. (2005) for designing the robust controller.

Olsson (2006) investigated the active automotive engine vibration isolation using the gain scheduled H2 controllers. A multi-body system analysis and simulation software for dynamics (ADAMS) was employed to simulate engine vibration behavior on the mounts. Also, a simple model (including control force, stiffness and damping elements) for active engine mounts was considered. Olsson (2006) designed the mentioned controller based on the engine model in ADAMS software, a simple model of active mount and without modeling the uncertainties.

In designing the model-based controllers (e.g. robust controllers), employing more accurate mathematical models for the plant (i.e. engine) and actuator (i.e. active engine mount) can improve the controller performance. In the present study, accurate mathematical models for engine vibration and also for active engine mount are employed to design robust controllers for engine vibration suppression. To the best of the authors’ knowledge, this matter has not been covered in the literature in the past. In addition, equations of motion for the considered model of engine on the mounts in this paper are derived using Lagrange's and Newton–Euler equations. This derivation of equations has not been presented in any other study.

The assumptions of the considered model for the engine are the same as the model presented by Hoffman and Dowling (2001). They employed Kane's analytical method to derive the relevant equations of motion. However, in this study, derivation of the equations of motion is performed using different methods (Lagrange's and Newton–Euler equations) that have not been presented in any other study.

In this paper, the effectiveness of an active engine mount in vibration suppression of a four-cylinder engine is evaluated. In Section 2, dynamic equations of motion for the engine on the mounts are derived using Lagrange's and Newton–Euler equations. In Section 3, the mentioned equations of motion are linearized and two robust control algorithms, namely H2 and H∞ schemes, are designed to provide control input using accelerations of the engine body in the position of the mounts. In designing robust controllers, unstructured uncertainties due to the unmodeled dynamics of the plant, actuator and sensors are considered. In Section 4, simulation results are presented and robust stability and robust performance of the proposed controllers are evaluated using µ-analysis. Also, the effectiveness of the mentioned controllers, in the presence of sensor noise, in vibration suppression of the engine is evaluated.

sec.title: 2. Dynamic equations of motion
sec.p: In order to predict the engine dynamics and vibrations, various models have been presented in the literature. Hoffman and Dowling (2001) have developed both one-way-coupled and fully coupled models for engine dynamics and vibrations. However, in most of studies one-way-coupled models have been developed and investigated.

In one-way-coupled models, it is assumed that rigid-body motions of the internal engine components (pistons, connecting rods, and the crankshaft) are dynamically uncoupled from the rigid-body motion of the engine block. In other words, it is assumed that only the motion of the piston–rod–crankshaft mechanism affect the engine block motion and the effect of engine block motion on the motion of internal engine components is not considered.

In this study, the one-way-coupled rigid-body model is employed. The assumptions of this model are the same as the model presented by Hoffman and Dowling (2001). They derived the dynamic equations of motion using Kane's analytical method. However, in this study, different methods (Lagrange's and Newton–Euler equations) are employed to derive the equations of motion.

The model is divided into two main components: the piston–rod–crankshaft model and the engine block displacement model. The first sub-model simulates the rigid-body nonlinear dynamics of the piston–rod–crankshaft mechanism, where all motions are defined using one degree of freedom (crankshaft angle). The second sub-model simulates engine block vibrations resulting in six rigid-body degrees of freedom describing the translation and rotation of the engine block. In this model, the small displacement and small angle approximation for engine block vibration is considered. This assumption is appropriate due to the small motions typically observed on properly mounted engines. Model inputs are cylinder pressure histories, an empirical model for the effective friction load torque, engine geometry, engine mount characteristics, and inertial properties of the engine and its components.

At first, the engine block is assumed stationary and the single-degree-of-freedom equation for piston–rod–crankshaft mechanism is derived. Then, the loads that the internal engine components generate on the stationary block are determined. Finally, these loads are used as the forcing input to a six-degree-of-freedom model for the engine block on resilient supports. In the following subsections, the governing dynamic equations of motion for the piston–rod–crankshaft mechanism and also for engine block supported by engine mounts are derived.

In deriving the dynamic equations of motions, the body-fixed engine block coordinate system (xyz) shown in Figure 1 is used. This coordinate system is fixed to the engine block and its origin is located in point O (the intersection of cylinder 1 axis and the crankshaft axis). Also, an inertial coordinate system (XYZ) is considered that its origin is located in point O while the engine is at rest. The unit vectors (i∧,j∧,k∧) and (I∧,J∧,K∧) are considered for engine block and inertial coordinate systems, respectively. Figure 1.
Schematic view of the considered engine block and inertial coordinate systems.

sec.title: 2.1. Piston–rod–crankshaft model
sec.p:
The rigid-body one-degree-of-freedom model for the piston–rod–crankshaft mechanism is schematically shown in Figure 2. In this model, the engine block is assumed stationary. A dynamic equation of motion for the piston–rod–crankshaft mechanism is derived and the loads that this mechanism generates on the stationary block are determined in the engine block coordinate system. Figure 2.
Schematic view of the piston–rod–crankshaft mechanism.

The rotation of the 1st crank from the cylinder axis is denoted by θ and the corresponding rotation for nth crank is presented by θn=θ+αn, where αn is the phase angle between the 1st crank and nth crank. Also, φn, zpn and N indicate the rotation of the nth connecting rod from the cylinder axis, z-component of nth piston center of mass position and number of cylinders, respectively.

In this study, all internal engine components rigidly rotating from the front of the engine (for example, a fan) to the rear (for example, the flywheel) are considered as crankshafts. It is assumed that crankshaft system mass is mcs and its mass moment of inertia tensor in its local coordinate system and engine block coordinate system are respectively denoted by [Ics'](xyz)cs and [Ics](xyz) (as presented in Appendix B). Mass of the nth connecting rod is presented by mcrn and its mass moment of inertia about an axis passing piston pin and perpendicular its plane is considered as Icr11n. Also, the mass of the nth piston is denoted by mpn.

The nonconservative external forces and moment applied to the piston–rod–crankshaft mechanism are combustion gas forces, effective load torque on the crankshaft, lateral piston forces and bearing reaction forces. It is noted that fgn, TLoad, fpn and fbn indicate combustion gas force in the nth cylinder, effective load torque on the crankshaft, lateral force on the nth piston and nth bearing reaction force, respectively. Combustion gas force is obtained from fgn = (Pgn π Dn2)/4, where Pgn and Dn denote combustion gas pressure in the nth cylinder and diameter of the nth piston, respectively.

The Lagrange's equations with holonomic constraints are employed to derive the dynamic equations of motion. These equations are presented as follows: (1)ddt(∂T∂q·j)-∂T∂qj+∂V∂qj=∑i=1M-NDλi∂fi∂qj+Qj j=1…M where T, V, qj and Qj present kinetic energy of the system, potential energy of the system, jth generalized coordinate and nonconservative generalized force corresponding to jth generalized coordinate, respectively. Also, M, ND, λi and fi denote the number of generalized coordinates, the number of degrees of freedom, ith Lagrange multiplier and ith holonomic constraint equation, respectively.

For the piston–rod–crankshaft model, 2N + 1 generalized coordinates (θ, φn and zpn) are selected. Also, 2N holonomic constraints can be considered as follows: (2)f1n=Rnsinθn-Lnsinφn=0f2n=zpn-Rncosθn-Lncosφn-dn=0 n=1…N where Rn, Ln and dn indicate the radius of nth crank, length of nth connecting rod and distance between the pin and the center of mass of nth piston (Gpn).

The kinetic energy of the piston–rod–crankshaft mechanism can be presented as follows (3)T=12Ics11'θ·2+∑i=1N12mpnz·pn2+∑n=1N12mcrnVGcrn2+∑n=1N12(Icr11n-mcrnln2)φ·n2 where VGcrn and ln denote the velocity of the nth connecting rod center of mass and distance between the nth piston pin and nth connecting rod center of mass (Gcrn), respectively. The velocity of the nth connecting rod center of mass in engine block coordinate system is presented by (4)V→Gcrn=lnφ·ncosφni∧+(z·pn+lnφ·nsinφn)j∧ n=1…N

For simplicity, the gravitational forces of the components in piston–rod–crankshaft model can be neglected. The mentioned forces are considered in engine block displacement model developed in the next subsection. Therefore, the piston–rod–crankshaft mechanism has no potential energy, that is, (5)V=0
The nonconservative generalized forces corresponding to the selected generalized coordinates are presented as follows (6)Qθ=-TLoad Qφn=0 Qzpn=-fgn n=1…N

Substituting Equations (2)–(6) into Equation (1), 2N + 1 differential equations of motion will be obtained as follows (7)Ics11'θ··=∑n=1N[λ1nRncosθn]+∑n=1N[λ2nRnsinθn]-TLoad (8)mcrnlnsinφnz··pn+Icr11nφ··n=-λ1nLncosφn+λ2nLnsinφn n=1…N (9)(mpn+mcrn)z··pn+mcrnlnφ··ssnsinφn+mcrnlnφ·n2cosφn =λ2n-fgn n=1…N

The above equations together with the 2N constraint equations (2) can be employed to determine generalized coordinates and 2N Lagrange multipliers. However, it is better to present the one-degree-of-freedom dynamic equation of motion in terms of θ for the piston–rod–crankshaft mechanism. Using constraint equations (2), φ·n, z·pn and z··pn can be presented in terms of θ· and θ·· as follows φ·n=-A1nθ· φ··n=-A1nθ··+B1nθ·2 z··pn=A2nθ··-B2nθ·2 n=1…N<label>(10)</label> where A1n=-RncosθnLncosφn (11)A2n=-Rncosφnsin(θn+φn) n=1…N (12)B1n=A1ntanθn+A1n2tanφnB2n=Rncosθn+tanθnA2n+LncosφnA1n2 n=1…N

Lagrange multipliers can be eliminated in Equations (7)–(9) by solving Equations (8) and (9) for λ1n and λ2n and substituting the obtained expressions into Equation (7). In this way, one differential equation of motion is obtained. Then, in this equation, φ·n, φ··n and z··pn are substituted from Equation (10). Finally, by considering the expressions for A1n and A2n from Equation (11), the one-degree-of-freedom dynamic equation of motion for the piston–rod–crankshaft mechanism in terms of θ is obtained as follows (13)I1θ··=I2θ·2-∑n=1N[A2n fgn]-TLoad where I1 and I2 are functions of the introduced parameters. In above equation, φn can be presented in terms of θ using the first relation of Equation (2).

In order to determine fpn and fbn, Newton–Euler equations are used for the crankshaft and each connecting rod and piston. It is noted that the notation y and z appearing as subscripts to a parameter indicate the corresponding components in the y and z directions of the engine block coordinate system.

The bearing reaction forces (fbn) can be replaced by a resulting force Fb and a resulting moment Mb in the origin of the engine block coordinate system (point O). The components of Fb and Mb in the engine block coordinate system can be presented as follows (14)Fby=∑n=1N fbyn Fbz=∑n=1N fbznMby=-∑n=1Nfbzncn Mbz=∑n=1Nfbyncn where cn indicates distance (along the crankshaft axis) from point O to the nth cylinder axis. Figure 3 shows the free-body diagrams of the crankshaft and each connecting rod and piston. In these diagrams, fppn denotes the reaction force between nth piston and nth connecting rod. Also, fcpn indicates the reaction force between the crankshaft and nth connecting rod. Using Newton–Euler equations for each component, fpn, Fby, Fbz, Mby and Mbz are obtained as follows (15)fpn=-Icr11n-mcrnln2Lncosφnφ··n+[z··crntanφn-y··crn]Ln-lnLnmcrn +[mpnz··pn+fgn]tanφnfby=∑n=1N[mcrny··crn+fpn]+mcsy··csfbz=mcsz··cs+∑n=1N[mcrnz··crn+mpnz··pn+fgn]Mby=Ics12θ··-Ics13θ·2-∑n=1N[mcrnz··crn+mpnz··pn+fgn]cnMbz=Ics13θ··+Ics12θ·2+∑n=1N(mcrny··crn+fpn)cn where ycrn and zcrn indicate the y- and z-components of the nth connecting rod center of mass position, respectively. Also, ycs and zcs denote the y- and z-components of the crankshaft center of mass position, respectively. It is noted that y··cs, z··cs,y··crn and z··crn appearing in the above equations can be presented in terms of θ· and θ·· using kinematics relations as follows (16)y··cs=-rθ·2sin(θ+δ)z··cs=rθ·2cos(θ+δ)y··crn=ln[A1ncosφnθ··+(A1n2sinφn-B1ncosφn)θ·2]z··crn=(A2n-lnA1nsinφn)θ·· -(B2n-B1nlnsinφn-lnA1n2cosφn)θ·2 where r and δ present radial position of crankshaft center of mass (Gcs) with respect to crankshaft axis and angular position of crankshaft center of mass with respect to the 1st crank axis, respectively. Also, φ··n and z··pn appearing in Equation (15) are presented in terms of θ, θ· and θ·· in Equation (10). Also, φn employed in Equations (15) and (16) is presented in terms of θ in Equation (2). Figure 3.
The free-body diagrams of the crankshaft and each connecting rod and piston.

By solving the one-degree-of-freedom dynamic equation of motion for the piston–rod–crankshaft mechanism (Equation (13)), θ and its time derivatives are obtained. Then, using Equation (15) components of lateral piston forces and bearing reaction loads in the engine block coordinate system are determined.

sec.title: 2.2. Engine block displacement model
sec.p:
In the engine block displacement model, the engine block is allowed to move and the pistons, connecting rods and crankshaft are fixed to the engine block. Therefore, the engine block displacement model can be described as a six-degree-of-freedom rigid body (consisting of the engine block and all fixed internal components) resiliently supported on engine mounts. Each mount is presented by a spring and damper in parallel. The piston–rod–crankshaft mechanism provides prescribed load inputs to the engine block displacement model. Figure 4 indicates the loads applied to the engine block including load inputs from the piston–rod–crankshaft mechanism (bearing reaction loads and lateral piston forces), combustion forces, the gravitational force and engine mounts forces. Figure 4.
Loads applied on the engine: (a) front view of the engine; and (b) side view of the engine.

It is assumed that the total displacement (static and dynamic) of point O in directions of inertial coordinate system axes are x, y and z. Also, the total rotation angles (static and dynamic) of the engine about the axes of inertial coordinate system are considered as θx, θy and θz. In this study, the engine rotation angles, time derivatives of engine displacements and rotation angles are considered small. Therefore, the terms including the second and higher orders of the mentioned small variables can be neglected.

In addition, it is assumed that the engine center of mass is stationary, that is, the position of engine center of mass and engine mass moments of inertia are considered in a specified crankshaft configuration (θ = θ0). The total mass of the engine is presented by m and the position vector of its center of mass (for θ = θ0) in engine block coordinate system is considered as follows (17)r→G=r1i∧+r2j∧+r3k∧
Also, the engine mass moment of inertia tensor (for θ = θ0) in the engine block coordinate system is presented as follows (18)[I](xyz)=[I11I12I13I12I22I23I13I23I33]

Newton–Euler equations of motion for engine can be presented as below (19)∑F→=ma→G∑M→O=→·HO+mr→G×a→O where ∑F→ and ∑M→O represent the resultant force and moment (about point O) applied to the engine, respectively. Also, →·HO, a→G and a→O denote the rate of angular momentum about point O, acceleration of engine center of mass and acceleration of point O, respectively.

In this study, dynamic equations of motion for the engine block displacement model are presented in the engine block coordinate system. It is noted that the rotation matrix from the inertial to the engine block coordinate system for the small engine rotation angles assumption is presented as follows <label>(20)</label>[RI]=[1θz-θy-θz1θxθy-θx1]

Using the above rotation matrix and neglecting the terms including the second and higher orders of small variables, a→O, a→G and →·HO in the engine block coordinate system are presented as follows (21)a→O=x··i∧+y··j∧+z··k∧a→G=(x··+r3θ··y-r2θ··z)i∧+(y··+r1θ··z-r3θ··x) +(z··+r2θ··x-r1θ··y)→·HO=[I11I12I13I12I22I23I13I23I33][θ··xθ··yθ··z]

The resultant force and moment (about point O) applied to the engine can be presented as (22)∑F→=F→bp+F→g+F→w+F→m∑M→O=M→bp+M→g+M→w+M→m where F→bp, F→g, F→w and F→m denote the resultant applied force from the piston–rod–crankshaft mechanism, the resultant combustion force, the gravitational force and the resultant engine mounts force, respectively. Also, M→bp, M→g, M→w and M→m represent the resultant moment of applied forces from the piston–rod–crankshaft mechanism, the resultant moment of combustion forces, the moment of gravitational force and the resultant moment of engine mounts forces about point O, respectively. The mentioned forces and moments are obtained in the following subsections.

Substituting Equations (17), (21) and (22) into Equation (19), the engine block displacement model equations of motion are presented as follows (23)[Me][x··y··z··θ··xθ··yθ··z]=[F→bpM→bp]+[F→gM→g]+[F→wM→w]+[F→mM→m] where (24)[Me]=[m000mr3-mr20m0-mr30mr100mmr2-mr100-mr3mr2I11I12I13mr30-mr1I12I22I23-mr2mr10I13I23I33]

sec.title: 2.2.1. Forces and moments from the piston–rod–crankshaft mechanism
sec.p: In Section 2.1, bearing reaction loads (F→b and M→b) and lateral piston forces (fpn) applied to the piston–rod–crankshaft mechanism were determined. Reactions of the mentioned loads are applied to the engine from the piston–rod–crankshaft mechanism, as shown in Figure 4. The resultant force applied to the engine from the piston–rod–crankshaft mechanism in the engine block coordinate system is presented as follows (25)F→bp=-F→b+∑n=1Nfpnj∧
The resultant moment of the mentioned loads about point O in the engine block coordinate system is presented as follows (26)M→bp=-M→b+∑n=1N[(cni∧+(zpn-dn)k∧)×fpnj∧]

sec.title: 2.2.2. Combustion forces and moments
sec.p: Combustion forces are applied to the engine block and on the pistons. Combustion forces applied on the pistons affect the load inputs from the piston–rod–crankshaft mechanism and therefore are considered in the previous subsection. Referring to Figure 4, the resultant combustion force applied to the engine block is presented as follows (27)F→g=∑n=1Nfgnk∧
The resultant moment of the mentioned forces about point O in the engine block coordinate system is presented as follows (28)M→g=-∑n=1Nfgncnj∧

sec.title: 2.2.3. Gravitational force and moment
sec.p: Gravitational force applied to the engine in the inertial coordinate system is presented by (29)F→w,XYZ=-mgK∧ where g denotes the gravitational acceleration. Using the rotation matrix (Equation (20)), the above vector in the engine block coordinate system is obtained as follows (30)F→w=[RI]F→w,XYZ
Moment of the gravitational force about point O in the engine block coordinate system is presented as follows (31)M→w=r→G×F→w

sec.title: 2.2.4. Engine mounts forces and moments
sec.p: In this study, it is assumed that the engine is supported by rubber and active mounts. The active mount has two parts: rubber and an active part. In this subsection, forces and moments applied to the engine by rubber mounts and also the rubber part of the active mount are derived. The applied forces and moments by the active part of the active mount are presented in the next section.

Each rubber mount and also the rubber part of the active mount can be modeled as three orthogonally placed springs and dampers in directions of their elastic axes. For each engine mount, a local coordinate system in the directions of its elastic axes is considered. The local coordinate system of the ith engine mount is denoted by (x∧y∧z∧)i. According to the orientation of each engine mount, a rotation matrix [A]i from the local coordinate system of the ith engine mount to the inertial coordinate system is considered. It is noted that the rotation matrix [A]i is orthogonal, that is, [A]i-1=[A]iT. The position vector of the ith mount in the engine block coordinate system is considered as follows (32)r→i=r1ii∧+r2ij∧+r3ik∧

The displacement vector of the engine in the position of the ith mount in the inertial coordinate system is presented as follows (33)Δr→i,(XYZ)=[xyz]T+[Rm1]iT[θxθyθz]T where (34)[Rm1]i=[0-r3ir2ir3i0-r1i-r2ir1i0]
The displacement vector of the engine in the position of the ith mount in its local coordinate system can be obtained by the rotation matrix [A]i as follows (35)Δr→i=[A]iTΔr→i,(XYZ)

Using the above equation and the force–displacement diagram of each mount, the applied force to the engine by each mount (due to stiffness) in its local coordinate system ( f→ki,(x∧y∧z∧)) can be obtained. Then, using the transformation matrix [A]i, the resultant force (due to stiffness) applied to the engine by the mounts in inertial coordinate system is obtained as follows (36)F→k,(XYZ)=∑i=1EMf→ki,(XYZ) where EM is the number of engine mounts and (37)f→ki,(XYZ)=[A]i f→ki,(x∧y∧z∧)
Finally, using the rotation matrix in Equation (20), the resultant force applied to the engine by the mounts in the engine block coordinate system is obtained as follows (38)F→k=[RI]F→k,(XYZ)

The moment of the applied force (due to stiffness) to the engine by the ith mount about point O in the inertial coordinate system can be presented as follows (39)M→k,(XYZ)=∑i=1EMM→ki,(XYZ) where (40)M→ki,(XYZ)=r→i,(XYZ)×f→ki,(XYZ)=[Rm2]i f→ki,(XYZ)

In the above equation, r→i,(XYZ) is the position vector of the ith mount in the inertial coordinate system and can be obtained using the rotation matrix in Equation (20) as follows (41)r→i,(XYZ)=[RI]Tr→i
Also, [Rm2]i is a function of the introduced parameters.

Finally, using the rotation matrix in Equation (20), the resultant moment of the applied forces (due to stiffness) by the mounts about point O in the engine block coordinate system is obtained as follows (42)M→k=[RI]M→k,(XYZ)

The applied force to the engine by each mount (due to damping) in its local coordinate system can be obtained as follows (43)f→ci,(x∧y∧z∧)=-[c]iΔ→·ri where [c]i is damping matrix of the ith mount in its local coordinate system as follows (44)[c]i=[c1i000c2i000c3i]

Also, Δ→·ri is the velocity vector of the engine in the position of the ith mount in its local coordinate system. In a similar way presented to obtain the applied forces and moments by the mounts due to stiffness, the corresponding forces and moments considering damping effects of the mounts can be obtained.

The resultant force and moment (about point O) applied to the engine by the mounts (due to damping) in the inertial coordinate system is obtained as follows (45)F→c,(XYZ)=∑i=1EMf→ci,(XYZ)M→c,(XYZ)=∑i=1EMM→ci,(XYZ) where (46)f→ci,(XYZ)=[A]i f→ci,(x∧y∧z∧)M→ci,(XYZ)=r→i,(XYZ)×f→ci,(XYZ)
The resultant force and moment (about point O) applied to the engine by the mounts (due to damping) in the engine block coordinate system is obtained as follows (47)F→c=[RI]F→c,(XYZ)M→c=[RI]M→c,(XYZ)

Finally, the resultant applied force and moment by the mounts considering stiffness and damping effects are presented as follows (48)F→m=F→k+F→c+F→aM→m=M→k+M→c+M→a where F→a and M→a denote the applied forces and moments by the active part of the active mount in the engine block coordinate system that are presented in the next section.

sec.title: 2.3. Active engine mount model
sec.p:
In this study, the active engine mount model presented by Lee and Lee (2009) is employed. The mentioned active engine mount has the basic structure of the conventional hydraulic engine mount, of which the decoupler is replaced by an electromagnetic actuator. The actuator actively controls the upper chamber pressure and therefore the transmitted force from the engine to the chassis can be canceled. Figure 5 indicates schematically the structure of the considered active engine mount. A dynamic model of the active engine mount presented by Lee and Lee (2009) is shown in Figure 6. In this figure, Kr and Cb denote the stiffness (in direction of the active system) and volumetric compliance of rubber, respectively. Also, Ae, Ac and At represent the equivalent cross-sectional area of the upper fluid chamber, the cross-sectional areas of the actuator runner and the inertia track, respectively. The fluid flow in the inertia track is modeled as the equivalent mass mt and damping coefficient Rt. The volumetric compliance of the lower chamber is denoted by Kt. Because the fluid flows in the peripheral direction as complying with the track’s geometry, the friction force against the fluid flow in the track is not directly transmitted to the chassis. Therefore, the inertia track is modeled such that it is connected to the absolute reference frame, not to the chassis. The active system is modeled as the runner mass mc and damping coefficient Rc, and the stiffness of the actuator’s mechanical spring is denoted by Kc. It is noted that the active system is directly connected to the base of the active engine mount. Here fc is the force generated by actuator that is applied to both the runner and the chassis. Figure 5.
Structure of the considered active engine mount. Reproduced with kind permission from Elsevier (Lee and Lee, 2009).
Figure 6.
Active engine mount model. Reproduced with kind permission from Elsevier (Lee and Lee, 2009).

Referring to Figure 6, P and xe represent the upper fluid chamber pressure, engine vibration in position of active mount in direction of the active system, respectively. Also, xc and xt denote the actuator runner displacement and the equivalent displacement of the inertia track equivalent mass, respectively.
Using the Newton equations for the actuator runner and inertia track equivalent mass, the following equations can be obtained (49)mtx··t+Rtx·t+Ktxt=-AtP-mtgmcx··c+Rcx·c+Kcxc=-AcP-mcg+fc
Also, the fluid continuity equation with the fluid incompressibility assumption can be presented as follows (50)Aex·e+CbP·=Atx·t+Acx·c
The transmitted force to the chassis in the direction of the active system is obtained as follows (51)Ftrans=Krxe-P(Ae-Ac)+Rcx·c+Kcxc-fc

The local coordinate system (x∧y∧z∧)a for the active mount is considered as shown in Figure 6. The force applied to the engine by the active part of the active mount in its local coordinate system can be presented as follows (52)F→a,(x∧y∧z∧)=[00PAe]T

Similar to Equation (37), the force applied to the engine by active part of the active mount in the inertial coordinate system can be presented as follows (53)F→a,(XYZ)=[A]aF→a,(x∧y∧z∧) where [A]a is the rotation matrix from local coordinate system of the active mount to the inertial coordinate system. Similar to Equation (38), the force applied to the engine by the active part of the active mount in the engine block coordinate system can be obtained as follows (54)F→a=[RI]F→a,(XYZ)

Similar to Equation (40), the moment of the applied force to the engine by active part of the active mount about point O in inertial coordinate system can be presented as follows (55)M→a,(XYZ)=r→a,(XYZ)×F→a,(XYZ)=[Rm2]aF→a,(XYZ) where [Rm2]a is a matrix similar to [Rm2]i (in Equation (40)) for active mount. Also, r→a,(XYZ) is the position vector of active mount in inertial coordinate system and can be obtained similar to Equation (41) as follows (56)r→a,(XYZ)=[RI]Tr→a

In above equation, r→a is the position vector of active mount in the engine block coordinate system. Finally, similar to Equation (42), the moment of the applied force by the active part of the active mount about point O in the engine block coordinate system is obtained as follows (57)M→a=[RI]M→a,(XYZ)
F→a and M→a presented in Equations (54) and (57) are employed in Equation (48).

sec.title: 3. The proposed controllers (H2 and H∞ schemes)
3.1. Backgrounds
sec.p: Two kinds of uncertainty can arise in the model: unstructured uncertainties (due to the unmodeled dynamics of the plant, actuators, sensors, etc.) and structured uncertainties (due to the variation of plant parameters caused by aging, etc.). Therefore, employing the robust controller schemes is necessary for real-world implementation of the controllers. In this study, two robust control algorithms, namely H2 and H∞ schemes are investigated.

Figure 7 represents the general block diagram of a control system with uncertainties, where P(s) and K(s) denote the transfer functions of the plant and the controller, respectively. Also, Δ indicates the uncertainties in the model. The input variable w→ represents all exogenous signals (disturbances acting on the control system), and the output performance variable z→ is an index of the performances to be attained by the control system. The measured output variable y→ is the input to the controller, while the control variable u→ is its output. The general state-space form of the controlled system (with nominal plant) can be presented as follows (58)→·x=[A]x→+[B1]w→+[B2]u→z→=[C1]x→+[D11]w→+[D12]u→y→=[C2]x→+[D21]w→+[D22]u→ where x→ is the state vector of the plant. The H2 (H∞) optimal control problems consists of finding an optimal controller K(s) that internally stabilizes P(s) and minimizes the H2 (H∞) norm of the closed-loop transfer matrix from the input w→ to the output z→ that is ‖Twz ‖2 ( ‖Twz ‖∞). Figure 7.
General block diagram of a control system with uncertainties.

sec.title: 3.2. Linearization of the system dynamics
sec.p: Equations of motions of the engine on the mounts presented in Equation (23) are nonlinear. In this study, the controllers are designed based on the linearized equations of motion. Active engine mounts are usually employed to suppress dynamic, not static, loads. Therefore, in order to design controllers, linearized equations of motion with neglecting static terms should be employed.

The nonlinear terms appeared in the equations of motions of the engine (Equation (23)) are the resultant applied force and moment by the mounts (F→m and M→m). In order to linearize the equations of motion, linear stiffness should be considered for the mounts (force–displacement diagrams of the mounts). It is assumed that the stiffness matrix of the ith mount in its local coordinate system are presented as follows (59)[k]i=[k1i000k2i000k3i]
The applied force (due to stiffness) by ith mount in its local coordinate system can be presented as follows (60)f→ki,(x∧y∧z∧)=-[k]iΔr→i

Considering linear stiffness for all mounts and using Equations (60), (38) and (42), the resultant force and moment applied to the engine by the mounts (due to stiffness) in the engine block coordinate system is obtained as follows (61)F→k=-[RI][Ktt][xyz]-[RI][Ktr][θxθyθz] (62)M→k=-[RI](∑i=1EM[Rm2]i[ktt]i)[xyz] -[RI](∑i=1EM[Rm2]i[ktt]i[Rm1]iT)[θxθyθz] where the matrices [Ktt] and [Ktr] are presented in Appendix A.

Equations (61) and (62) are still nonlinear. The total displacements and rotations of the engine can be divided into instantaneous static and dynamic components, that is, (63)x=x0+x' θx=θx0+θ'xy=y0+y' θy=θy0+θ'yz=z0+z' θz=θz0+θ'z

In above equations, the subscript 0 denotes the static component and the superscript prime represents the dynamic component. Static rotations, dynamic displacements and rotations, and also time derivatives of displacements and rotations of the engine can be assumed to be small. These assumptions are employed for linearization of Equations (61) and (62). It is noted that static displacements of the engine cannot be assumed to be small because of the large weight of the engine on flexible mounts.
The matrices [RI] and [Rm2]i can be presented as follows (64)[RI]=[I]+[ΔRI] (65)[Rm2]i=[Rm1]i+[ΔRm]i where [I] is identity matrix. Also, [ΔRI] and [ΔRm]i are functions of the introduced parameters.

Substituting Equations (63), (64) and (65) into Equations (61) and (62), neglecting the terms including the second and higher orders of small variables and using the following relation (66)[ΔRI][Rm1]i+[ΔRm]i=[Rm1]i[ΔRI] the following linear equations are obtained: (67)F→k=-[Ktt][xyz]-[Ktr][θxθyθz]-[ΔRI][Ktt][x0y0z0] (68)M→k=-[Krt][xyz]-[Krr][θxθyθz]-[K'rt][x0y0z0] where the matrices [Krt], [Krr] and [K'rt] are presented in Appendix A. The last terms in Equations (67) and (68) can be presented as follows (69)[ΔRI][Ktt][x0y0z0]=[F1][θxθyθz][K'rt][x0y0z0]=[F2][θxθyθz] where matrices [F1] and [F2] are functions of static displacements x0, y0 and z0. Using Equations (43) and (47), the similar equations to Equations (61) and (62) are obtained for damping effects of the mounts (F→c and M→c) that are nonlinear. Using the similar procedure for linearization of F→k and M→k (in Equations (61) and (62)), the following linear equations for F→c and M→c are obtained (70)F→c=-[Ctt][x·y·z·]-[Ctr][θ·xθ·yθ·z] (71)M→c=-[Crt][x·y·z·]-[Crr][θ·xθ·yθ·z] where the matrices [Ctt], [Ctr], [Crt] and [Crr] are presented in Appendix A.

The displacements xe, xc and xt and the pressure P presented in the active engine mount model (Section 2.3) can be divided into instantaneous static and dynamic components. Therefore, similar to Equation (63), the following relations can be presented (72)xe=xe0+x'e xc=xc0+x'cxt=xt0+x't P=P0+P'
Dynamic displacements x't and x'c can be assumed to be small. Substituting Equation (72) into Equation (50), the following equation can be obtained (73)Aex·'e+CbP·'=Atx·'t+Acx·'c

The above equation can be integrated with zero initial conditions for dynamic displacements x'e, x'c and x't and dynamic pressure P' as follows (74)Aex'e+CbP'=Atx't+Acx'c where x'e can be obtained using Equation (35) for active mount. Substituting Equations (72), (64), a relation for [Rm2]a similar to Equation (65) and P' (from Equation (74)) into Equations (54) and (57), neglecting the terms including the second and higher orders of small variables and using Equation (66), the following linear equations are obtained (75)F→a=-[Ktta1][x'y'z']+[Ktta2][x'tx'c]-[Ktra][θ'xθ'yθ'z] +[A]a[00P0Ae]+[ΔRI][A]a[00P0Ae] (76)M→a=-[Krta1][x'y'z']+[Krta2][x'tx'c]-[Krra][θ'xθ'yθ'z]+[Rm1]a[A]a[00P0Ae]+[Rm1]a[ΔRI][A]a[00P0Ae] where the stiffness matrices appearing in the above equations are presented in Appendix A. The last terms in Equations (75) and (76) can be presented as follows (77)[ΔRI][A]a[00P0Ae]=[F3][θxθyθz] [Rm1]a[ΔRI][A]a[00P0Ae]=[F4][θxθyθz] where matrices [F3] and [F4] are functions of static pressure P0. Using Equations (67), (68), (70), (71), (75), (76), (48) and (23), linearized engine block displacement model equations of motion will be obtained. Then, by substituting Equation (63) into obtained equations and neglecting static terms, linearized engine block displacement model equations of motion without static terms are presented as follows (78)[Me][x··'y··'z··'θ··'xθ··'yθ··'z]+[Ce][x·'y·'z·'θ·'xθ·'yθ·'z]+[Ke1][x'y'z'θ'xθ'yθ'z]+[Ke2][x'tx'c]=[F→bpM→bp]+[F→gM→g] where the damping and stiffness matrices appearing in the above equation are presented in Appendix A.
Substituting Equation (72) into Equation (49) and neglecting static terms, the following equations can be obtained (79)mtx··'t+Rtx·'t+Ktx't=-AtP'mcx··'c+Rcx·'c+Kcx'c=-AcP'+fc

By obtaining the dynamic pressure P' from Equation (74) and substituting into Equation (79), the reduced equations of motion for active engine mount without static terms are presented as follows (80)[Ma][x··'tx··'c]+[Ca][x·'tx·'c]+[Ka1][x'tx'c]+[Ka2][x'y'z']+[Ka3][θ'xθ'yθ'z]=[01]fc where the mass, damping and stiffness matrices appearing in the above equation are presented in Appendix A.

Using Equations (78) and (80), linearized dynamic equations of motion of engine supported by rubber and active mounts including active mount dynamic model can be presented as follows (81)[Msys][x··'y··'z··'θ··'xθ··'yθ··'zx··'tx··'c]+[Csys][x·'y·'z·'θ·'xθ·'yθ·'zx·'tx·'c]+[Ksys][x'y'z'θ'xθ'yθ'zx'tx'c]=[F→bp+F→gM→bp+M→g00]+[00000001]fc where (82)[Msys]=[[Me][0][0][Ma]][Csys]=[[Ce][0][0][Ca]][Ksys]=[[Ke1][Ke2][[Ka2][Ka3]][Ka1]]

By considering the following state vector, the linearized dynamic motion equations of the engine can be presented in the state-space form. (83)x→=[[x'y'z'θ'xθ'yθ'zx'tx'c]T[x·'y·'z·'θ·'xθ·'yθ·'zx·'tx·'c]T]

The plant inputs are divided into two groups. The first group includes disturbance forces and moments (d→) and also sensor noise (n→). The resultant applied force from the piston–rod–crankshaft mechanism, the resultant combustion force and the resultant moments of the mentioned forces are considered as disturbance forces and moments, i.e. (84)d→=[F→bp+F→gM→bp+M→g00]
The second group (u) is the force applied to the engine by actuator of the active engine mount (control input), u = fc.

In this study, it is assumed that accelerations of the engine block in connections of the mounts in the x, y and z directions of the engine block coordinate system are determined by sensors. These accelerations are considered as measured outputs (y→m).

sec.title: 3.3. Uncertainty representation
sec.p: In this study, the unstructured uncertainties are used to represent the unmodeled dynamics of the plant, sensors and actuator. The additive uncertainty is used to represent the errors caused by the model approximation of the plant in the high-frequency range. Moreover, in order to represent the unmodeled dynamics and the inefficiency of the actuator and sensors in the low-frequency range, a multiplicative uncertainty representation is used (Seba et al., 2005).

The additive uncertainty associated with the unmodeled dynamics of the plant is considered for the transfer function between u and y→m (Puy). The block diagram of the nominal plant with different uncertainties is shown in Figure 8, where Pdy(Puy) denotes the transfer function between d→ (u) and y→m. Also, the blocks Δa and ΔS represent the multiplicative uncertainty due to the unmodeled dynamics of the actuator and sensors in the low-frequency range, respectively. Also, the additive uncertainty Δm is used to represent the unmodeled dynamics of the plant in the high-frequency range. The weighting functions Wa, [Ws] and Wm are selected based on the a priori knowledge about the size of the uncertainties in the frequency domain, the inaccuracy size of the actuator and the noise characteristics in the sensor measurement. Also, they are selected in a way that the uncertainties are normalized, i.e. (85) ‖Δa ‖∞<1, ‖Δm ‖∞<1, ‖ΔS ‖∞<1 Figure 8.
The block diagram of the nominal plant with different uncertainties.

In order to account for the unmodeled dynamics of the sensors and actuator in the low-frequency range (below the mechanical resonance frequency of the sensors and actuator), more weight on this range of frequency should be considered. After the shape of the weighting functions has been chosen, trial and error is used to tune the amplitude of the weighting functions.

By pulling out the uncertain parameters from the known part of the model, the uncertain model in Figure 8 can be presented in the form of an upper linear fractional transformation (LFT) as shown in Figure 9 with a matrix Δ of uncertain parameters: (86)Δ=[Δa[0][0][0]Δm[0][0][0]ΔS] Figure 9.
Plant model in the form of an upper linear fractional transformation (LFT).

sec.title: 3.4. Performance requirements
sec.p: The aim of the controller design is to reduce the total transmitted force to the chassis and also the prevention of actuator saturation in the presence of exogenous inputs (sensor noise and disturbances) in the range of engine operation (about 800–6000 rpm). In other words, it is required to reduce the total transmitted force to the chassis and limit the actuator force. Therefore, the controller should minimize the effect of exogenous inputs on total transmitted force to the chassis and actuator force.

In robust controller design, choosing the weighting functions is crucial for obtaining meaningful engineering results. As a matter of fact, the weighting functions are design parameters that enable the designer to tune the controller in order to achieve the desired performance characteristics. The control input u is weighted by the weighting function Wu so as to prevent the saturation of controller output. Also, the weighting function matrix [WF] is employed to reflect the cost (penalty) functions for the total transmitted force to the chassis by all engine mounts (F→tot). The sensor noise (n→) and disturbances (d→) are weighted by the weighting function matrices [Wn] and [Wd], respectively. The mentioned weighting functions are selected with more weight on the range of engine operation (about 800–6000 rpm).

The block diagram of the linearized model of the engine supported by rubber and active mounts with the mentioned weighting functions (augmented plant) is shown in Figure 10. Figure 10.
Block diagram of the closed-loop system with the weighting functions.

sec.title: 3.5. H2 and H∞ design
sec.p: In order to design a robust controller, the disturbance forces and moments and sensor noises are considered as exogenous inputs (w→). Also, the output performance variables (z→) include the weighted control effort and the weighted total transmitted force to the chassis. Therefore, (87)w→=[d→n→] z→=[Wu u→[WF] F→tot]

By considering the state vector presented in equation (83), linearized dynamic equations of motion of the engine supported by rubber and active mounts (Equation (81)) considering the weighting functions Wu, [WF], [Wn] and [Wd] are presented in the state-space form of Equation (58). Therefore, the model in Figure 10 can be presented in standard form as shown in Figure 7. In this study, H2 and H∞ controllers are designed using MATLAB, Robust Control Toolbox.

sec.title: 4. Simulation results and discussion
sec.p: Ohadi and Maghsoodi (2007) investigated the efficiency of hydraulic engine mounts compared with the rubber mounts in a previous study. In this paper, the effectiveness of an active engine mount in vibration suppression of a four-cylinder engine is evaluated. Also, nonlinear stiffness characteristics for engine mounts are considered. The considered parameters in the simulation for the engine and the mounts are presented in Appendices B and C.

In addition, the load torques and combustion pressure histories required for simulation are employed from experiments. It is noted that the mentioned data was available for engine speeds from 1000 to 6000 rpm with the steps of 500 rpm. In this study, the robust controllers have been designed based on linearized equations of motion of the engine on the mounts. However, these controllers are applied to the nonlinear model of the engine on the mounts in simulations. he vibration behavior of the engine and performance of the active mount with the proposed controllers are simulated using MATLAB SIMULINK.

It is noted that the optimal weighting functions Wu, [WF], [Wn] and [Wd] were selected in designing each controller (H2 and H∞). In the implementation of controllers, high-order controllers will lead to high cost, difficult commissioning, poor reliability and potential problems in maintenance. Therefore, it is desirable to design low-order controllers. In this study, the order of the designed controllers are 37. The order of H2 and H∞ controllers respectively can be reduced to an order of 16 and 14 with Hankel-norm approximation method using MATLAB, with preserved performance and stability.

In order to investigate the nominal performance of the closed-loop system with the designed controllers, structured singular values (µ) of the transfer function Twz in the frequency domain is shown in Figure 11. It is clear that the maximum singular values associated with both controllers are less than 1. Therefore, the nominal performance is achieved within a large margin. Figure 11.
Nominal performance of the closed-loop system.

The robust performance and robust stability of the closed-loop system with H2 and H∞ controllers are investigated by means of the µ-analysis. The frequency response of µ for the case of robust stability and robust performance analysis are given in Figures 12 and 13, respectively. It is clear that robust stability and robust performance of the closed-loop system are achieved with both controllers. Figure 12.
Robust stability of the closed-loop system.
Figure 13.
Robust performance of the closed-loop system.
In this study, high-frequency Gaussian white noise in measurements is considered. It is assumed that the maximum disturbance in measurements is ±5% of real values.

The time domain response of the engine displacement in the z-direction and transmitted force to the chassis in the vertical direction with and without H∞ control are presented in Figures 14 and 15, respectively. The engine speed of 3500 rpm is considered. Figures 16 and 17 indicate the corresponding results with and without H2 control. The engine speed of 5000 rpm is considered. Figures 14–17 show that at the mentioned engine speeds the robust controllers reduce the amplitude of the transmitted force to the chassis in the vertical direction and do not have a considerable effect on the amplitude of the engine displacement in the z-direction. Figure 14.
Time response of the engine displacement in the z-direction with and without H∞ control at 3500 rpm.
Figure 15.
Time response of the transmitted force to the chassis in the vertical direction with and without H∞ control at 3500 rpm.
Figure 16.
Time response of engine displacement in the z-direction with and without H2 control at 5000 rpm.
Figure 17.
Time response of the transmitted force to the chassis in the vertical direction with and without H2 control at 5000 rpm.

Amplitude of the transmitted force to the chassis in the vertical direction for various engine speeds with and without robust controllers is shown in Figure 18. Referring to Figure 18, it is clear that active mount with both types of controllers reduces the amplitude of the transmitted force to the chassis in the vertical direction in the presence of sensor noise. Also, Figure 19 indicates the amplitude of control effort associated with the robust controllers for various engine speeds. This figure shows that H2 control requires less control effort compared with H∞ control to achieve the performances presented in Figure 18. Figure 18.
Amplitude of the transmitted force to the chassis in the vertical direction for various engine speeds.
Figure 19.
Amplitude of the control effort for various engine speeds.

sec.title: 5. Conclusion
sec.p: In this study, the effectiveness of an active engine mount in vibration suppression of a four-cylinder engine using two robust control algorithms, namely H2 and H∞ schemes, was evaluated. In order to design robust controllers, accurate mathematical models for engine vibration and also for active engine mount were employed. Dynamic equations of motion for an engine on the mounts were derived using Lagrange's and Newton–Euler equations.

In robust controller design, unstructured uncertainties due to the unmodeled dynamics of the plant, actuator and sensors were considered. Simulation results show that the active mount with the mentioned controllers improve the vibration behavior of the engine in the presence of sensor noise. Also, it is observed that considerable control effort is required to improve the vibration behavior of the engine with the designed controllers. It can be because of employing one active engine mount or using an active engine mount in improper position and orientation. Positioning the active engine mount in an optimal position (or orientation) or using two active mounts, the vibration behavior of the engine can be improved and less control effort will be required. Investigation on the optimal position and orientation of active engine mounts is proposed for future studies.

ack.p: The authors gratefully acknowledge the Irankhodro Powertrain Company (IPCo) for supplying required data for engine and rubber mounts.

sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

sec.title: Appendix A
sec.p: Several of the matrices used throughout the article are as follows: [Ktt]=∑i=1EM[ktt]i, [ktt]i=[A]i[k]i[A]iT, [Ktr]=∑i=1EM[ktr]i, [ktr]i=[ktt]i[Rm1]T, [Krt]=∑i=1EM[krt]i, [krt]i=[Rm1]i[ktt]i, [Krr]=∑i=1EM[krr]i, [krr]i=[Rm1]i[ktt]i[Rm1]iT [K'rt]=∑i=1EM[k'rt]i, [k'rt]i=[Rm1]i[ΔRI][ktt]i [Ctt]=∑i=1EM[ctt]i, [ctt]i=[A]i[c]i[A]iT [Ctr]=∑i=1EM[ctr]i [ctr]i=[ctt]i[Rm1]iT, [Crt]=∑i=1EM[crt]i, [ctr]i=[Rm1]i[ctt]i, [Crr]=∑i=1EM[crr]i, [crr]i=[Rm1]i[ctt]i[Rm1]iT, [Ktta1]=1Cb[A]a[00Ae][00Ae][A]aT [Ktta2]=1Cb[A]a[00Ae][AtAc] [Ktra]=[Ktta1][Rm1]aT [Krta1]=[Rm1]a[Ktta1] [Krra]=[Rm1]a[Ktra] [Krta2]=[Rm1]a[Ktta2] [Ce]=[[Ctt][Ctr][Crt][Crr]] [Ke1]=[[Ktt]+[Ktta1][Ktr]+[Ktra]+[F1]-[F3][Krt]+[Krta1][Krr]+[Krra]+[F2]-[F4]] [Ke2]=-[[Ktta2][Krta2]] [Ma]=[mt00mc] [Ka1]=[Kt+At2CbAtAcCbAtAcCbKc+Ac2Cb] [Ka2]=-AeCb[AtAc][001][A]aT [Ka3]=-AeCb[AtAc][001][A]aT[Rm1]aT [Ca]=[Rt00Rc]

sec.title: Appendix B. Parameters of the engine and its components
B.1. Engine parameters
sec.p: Engine parameters are given in Table 1.

sec.title: B.2. Crankshaft parameters
sec.p:
A body-fixed local coordinate systems ((xyz)cs) is considered for the crankshaft as shown in Figure 20. The origin of this coordinate system is considered in point O (the intersection of cylinder 1 axis and the crankshaft axis). The crankshaft mass moment of inertia tensor in its local coordinate system is presented by [Ics'](xyz)cs=[Ics11'Ics12'Ics13'Ics12'Ics22'Ics23'Ics13'Ics23'Ics33'] Figure 20.
Body-fixed local coordinate system of the crankshaft.

Crankshaft mass moment of inertia tensor in the engine block coordinate system can be obtained by [Ics](xyz)=[Rcs][Ics'](xyz)cs[Rcs]T=[Ics11Ics12Ics13Ics12Ics22Ics23Ics13Ics23Ics33] where [Rcs] is the rotation matrix about the x-axis with the angle of –θ as follows [Rcs]=[1000cos(-θ)sin(-θ)0-sin(-θ)cos(-θ)]

tr.td: Elements of the engine mass moment of inertia tensor in the engine block coordinate system
Elements of the position vector of the engine center of mass

sec.p:
The crankshaft parameters are given in Table 2. Table 2.
Crankshaft parameters
Crankshaft massmcs22.53 kg
Elements of the crankshaft mass moment of inertia tensor in its local coordinate system I'cs11 0.114 kg m2
I'cs12 0.94 × 10−4 kg m2
I'cs13 0.51 × 10−4 kg m2
I'c22 1.254 kg m2

I'cs33 1.245 kg m2
Radial position of the crankshaft center of mass with respect to the crankshaft axis R 0.09 × 10−3 m
Angular position of the crankshaft center of mass with respect to the 1st crank axis δ 2.08 rad
Radius of the nth crank Rn 42.5 × 10−3 m
Distance (along the crankshaft axis) from point O to nth cylinder axis cn 0.084 (n − 1) m
The phase angle between the 1st crank and nth crank αn 0, −π, −π, 0 rad
Firing order 1-3-4-2

sec.p:

Diameter of the nth piston Dn 0.0786 m

sec.title: C.1. Active engine mount
sec.p:
The parameters of the rubber part of the active engine mount are listed in Table 5 and the parameters of the nonrubber parts are listed in Table 6. Figure 21 shows a force–displacement diagram of the rubber part of the active engine mount in the y∧-direction. Figure 21.
Force–displacement diagram of the rubber part of the active engine mount in the y∧-direction. Table 5.
Parameters of the rubber part of the active engine mount
Static stiffness in the local coordinate systemx∧-direction50000 N/m
y∧-directionNonlinear (as shown in Figure 21)
z∧-direction133067 N/m
Loss angle (at 1 mm displacement amplitude) 5o
Elements of the position vector r11 −0.150 m
r21 −0.002 m
r31 0.305 m
Rotation matrix from the local coordinate system to the inertial coordinate system [A]a
[1000-1000-1]
Table 6.
Parameters of the active engine mount (nonrubber parts) (Lee and Lee, 2009)
Equivalent cross-sectional area of the upper fluid chamber Ae 3.337 × 10 − 3 m2
Cross-sectional area of the actuator runner Ac 1.256 × 10−3 m2
Cross-sectional area of the inertia track At 2 × 10−5 m2
Equivalent mass of fluid flow in the inertia track mt 5.1 × 10−3 kg
Runner mass mc 7.85 × 10−2 kg
Damping coefficient of fluid flow in the inertia track Rt 0.18 Ns/m
Damping coefficient of the active system Rc 10 Ns/m
Volumetric compliance of the lower chamber Kt 1 N/m
Stiffness of the actuator’s mechanical spring Kc 1.14 × 105 N/m
Volumetric compliance of rubber Cb 5 × 10−11 m5/N

sec.title: C.3. Torque strut
sec.p:
The torque strut has large and small parts. These parts are connected in series and the related parameters are presented in Table 8. Figure 22.
